data.text: Who Takes Spare Shoes When Bicycle Touring?

Super boring question, my apologies. Who takes spare shoes when touring? I seem to remember my last trip I was constantly trying to dry my trainers. I do now have waterproof socks so thought I could pop them on when camping etc. Nothing worse than putting on wet shoes in the morning.
Not spare cycle shoes. But shower/beach sandals and/or light trainers depending on climate. If I‚Äôm expecting a cold wet trip then waterproof socks can make wet cycle shoes less unpleasant.
data.author: John Knapp

data.text: I bring flip flops and pretty much wear them 99% of the time off the bike. I don't do anything close to cold weather touring though.
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: I carry 3 pairs.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: I don‚Äôt carry spare shoes because they take up so much space. If you can access it stuffing your shoes with newspaper overnight dries them very quickly.
data.author: Lynne Meredith

data.text: Off bike shoes like keens (that protect your toes). On one tour we were planning on doing hiking so even took hiking boots (This tour was 13 month). Flip flops for showers in hostels and for quick foot covering for camp and out of the tent during the night.
data.author: Rachel Hugens

data.text: We always carry cycling overshoes and some flip flops to
data.author: Sally Lloyd

data.text: I switched to flats a few years ago, so just wear Keens light hikers for almost everything, plus a pair of super light flip flops for showers and around camp.
data.author: Lee Carruthers

data.text: Depends on the tour. If I'm going light & fast, not usually (unless it's the height of summer, at which point I bring flip flops). If I'm doing a comfort trip, yes (usually a pair of minimalist trail runners). The difference is between carrying ~20 L of gear/food and bringing ~35 L of food/gear.
data.author: John Almond

data.text: Friend in Seattle rode in the rain bike sandals and neoprene kayak socks The sandals work has water can‚Äôt collect in them Polyester socks don‚Äôt hold tons of water and dry fast
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: Note that I always bring spare socks.
data.author: John Almond

data.text: Back in the day, I had a pair of cycling shoes that I could also walk in and also a pair of sneakers for times off the bike.
data.author: Edward Justyk

data.text: i just carry one pair of MTB shoes for 3 Weeks (Yikes)üòÅ. So far they dried over night very well, Twice i checked into a hotel as rain was just too much. i used the hairdryer to get the shoes dry again. I Also have no issue slipping into moist shoes in the morning, by noon they will be dry. As for odor i cnn highly recomend Baking powder sprinkeld under and on the insole. That reduces odor very much.
data.author: Andreas Madreiter

data.text: do the water proof socks work ? Cycling in Jura and France
data.author: Martin Clarke

data.text: I use Shimano SPD sandals and have worn these as my primary footwear on and off the bike for over 10 years now. If you are not touring in very cold weather, they also have the advantage they dry super quick. I have managed BRIEF spells even down to below freezing, combined with Sealskinz waterproof socks and shoe covers, but I wouldn't recommend this for where you know you will have significant extended cold weather, when I lived in Ireland I would wear them about half the year. I now live in the tropics and rarely see very low temperatures, so all year, I don't use anything else. These also aren't suitable for very long distance hiking due to the cleat being slippery, I bought some cheap trail runners for example to do the Annapurna Circuit in Nepal, that also involved some snow and wouldn't have been fun in sandals. But for day to day walking around they are fine, they are not super stiff and are quite walkable. So I don't need to bring two pairs.
data.author: Ivan McAvinchey

data.text: For the past couple of decades, I've only toured in sandals. I hate washing socks.
data.author: Loree L N√©eMurray Westron

data.text: We do. Skechers have very light walking shoes.
data.author: Debbie Miles

data.text: Biking shoes plus cheap plastic sandals from a market. Feet get wet from how much I sweat anyway. If it's a wet climate I ride in trekking sandals and socks.
data.author: Derek Poshtar

data.text: Yes, I carabiner a pair of sandals. I have a pair of waterproof socks I have used on my hands during rain or to stay warmer on cold mornings.
data.author: Michele Bauer

data.text: Me! These are Sauconys. They weigh basically nothing. It‚Äôs what I wear when I‚Äôm not biking. Great walking shoes.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: I do! There‚Äôs nothing quite like the feeling of taking off the shoes I‚Äôve had on all day for some camp shoes. Sometimes it‚Äôs crocs, sometimes it‚Äôs flip flops. Depends on where I‚Äôm headed and what I‚Äôll be doing :)
data.author: Lindsey Hamma

data.text: In the summer - Croc flip flops that weigh next to nothing. Colder seasons - flip flops plus trainers or walking shoes/boots.
data.author: Sara Ferrington

data.text: Just stuff the wet shoes with newspaper overnight and they'll dry. But it's a good idea to bring flip flops to prevent getting toenail fungus from shower stalls.
data.author: Chris Daigle
Charles Nighbor
Charles Nighbor

data.text: I use flat pedals, so I can cycle in any type of shoe. I bring sneakers and a very light pair of sandals that can go in water. I can bike in the sandals, use them in campground showers or when walking in rivers or lakes, or just use them as all around camp shoes.
data.author: Michele Bernhard

data.text: I usually bring as light a pair of running shoes (trainers) as possible for walking around. The biking shoes I use are okay for walking, but not as comfy.
data.author: Carlos Alcala

data.text: Look up Fitkicks which is a lightweight "shoe" that packs nearly flat, are not real rugged, but feel great for off-tour lounging.
data.author: Jonathan Harman

data.text: I always bring sandals. (Keen)
data.author: Cindy Burke

data.text: I use the Vibram Furoshiki as a camp shoe. Super lightweight and packable with its small bag.
data.author: Enrique Baires

data.text: Absolute great shoes! And really comfy to wear.. love mine
data.author: Kenneth Benjamins

data.text: I've gone both ways - just traveling with bike shoes, and bringing an extra pair of light gym shoes. I've tended towards more minimalism in terms of gear the last few years so I've mostly not carried extra shoes recently. But I've also traveled in some dryer/more desert locales. Definitely nothing wrong with bring a spare pair of shoes if it makes you happy and comfortable!
data.author: Jason Partridge

data.text: Barefoot shoes of any kind work great. I ride in xeroshoes sandals and love them. I occasionally bring my Lems Primal 2 sneakers which also weigh nothing
data.author: Liam Terry

data.text: I had the problem that my only shoes lost their soles‚Ä¶ had luck to buy some new ones in the next city‚Ä¶ next time I should bring spares‚Ä¶
data.author: Klaus-Dieter Jungermann

data.text: We tried touring with only our riding shoes‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.never again! Got caught in a day of freezing wet weather, totally drenched and no dry shoes.
data.author: Garry James

data.text: Two pair of cleated bike shoes one pair of street shoes.
data.author: Michael Fluke

data.text: Pair of sneakers and my Keene Sandals is all I bring.
data.author: Brian Sculac

data.text: On long trips I take camp shoes but if I am out just for a few days I don't. I have SPD sandals that are surprisingly comfortable to walk in but not everyday is a sandal day.
data.author: James Schoettgen

data.text: My Birkenstocks. Like wearing marshmallows after a ride. Ahhhh!
data.author: Kibbe McClod

data.text: I take sneakers to walk around town.
data.author: Steve Farmer

data.text: Trail running shoes and tewa sandals works for me.
data.author: Mojca Visner

data.text: Absolutely. Usually either flip flops or super light weight running shoes that will strap down flat on my rear bag.
data.author: Tyler Robertson

data.text: I take flip flops and wear cycling shies for riding. Flip flops are compact, lightweight, and let your feet breathe after being in ur shoes all day they just feel nice plus u can go into water and just shake them off and not worry about them retaining water.
data.author: Richard Tydryszewski

data.text: I wear Sandals for everything. Don't pedal in the cold that much as I live in the southeast.
data.author: Doug Ford

data.text: Same here! I have Teva sandals that I just love peddling in. They are comfortable, lets lots of air flow, dry easy, don't get damaged when wet, etc.
data.author: Norm Snyder

data.text: well... its nice to wrap up the day, in a loose fitting sandal as you walk around to loosen up your legs. so yeah, I would carry an extra footwear just for camping at night, to let my cycling shoes dry and breathe.
data.author: Paul Kvarnberg

data.text: If you don‚Äôt want to take a second pair of shoes plastic bags over dry socks into wet shoes does the trick! They‚Äôre still wet in the morning but at least you‚Äôre able to camp and walk around with dry feet. It might need some explaining if you‚Äôre eating out!!!
data.author: Ian Husband
